questions.question: Which of the following best describes a Software Process Model?
questions.option_a: A. A method defining how SDLC phases are executed
questions.option_b: B. A tool for automatic coding
questions.option_c: C. A guideline for project budgeting
questions.explanation: A software process model defines how SDLC phases are organized and executed to build a software product.

questions.question: What differentiates SDLC from Software Process Models?
questions.option_a: A. SDLC defines what phases to follow
questions.option_b: B. Process models define how to execute those phases
questions.option_c: C. SDLC is used only for agile projects
questions.explanation: SDLC defines the phases of development, while process models describe how those phases are performed.

questions.question: Which of the following is a traditional software process model?
questions.option_a: A. Waterfall
questions.explanation: The Waterfall model is a traditional, linear software process model used before modern agile methods.

questions.question: Which is a key feature of the Waterfall Model?
questions.option_a: A. Linear step-by-step process
questions.explanation: The Waterfall model follows a linear sequence where each phase must be completed before the next begins.

questions.question: Which scenario is most suitable for using the Waterfall Model?
questions.option_a: A. Payroll system with fixed requirements
questions.option_c: C. Research prototype with uncertain needs
questions.explanation: The Waterfall model is suitable when requirements are clear, stable, and unlikely to change.

questions.question: What improvement does the Iterative Waterfall Model bring over the classic one?
questions.option_a: A. Allows returning to previous phases
questions.explanation: The iterative Waterfall model introduces feedback by allowing teams to revisit earlier phases when necessary.

questions.question: When should the Iterative Waterfall Model be used?
questions.option_a: A. When minor changes are expected
questions.option_b: B. When feedback is available after each phase
questions.explanation: The iterative Waterfall model works best when requirements are mostly stable but may need minor revisions.

questions.question: Which statement is true about the V-Model?
questions.option_a: A. Testing is planned parallel to development phases
questions.option_c: C. It delays testing until after implementation
questions.explanation: In the V-Model, testing activities are planned alongside development phases for better validation and verification.

questions.question: Which of the following systems is most suitable for the V-Model?
questions.option_a: A. Medical devices
questions.explanation: The V-Model is ideal for safety-critical systems like medical or aerospace software where testing rigor is essential.

questions.question: Which is a key benefit of the Prototyping Model?
questions.option_a: A. Helps clarify user requirements through feedback
questions.option_d: D. Works best for rigid specifications
questions.explanation: Prototyping helps identify user needs early by showing a preliminary version of the system for feedback.

questions.question: Which step comes first in the Prototyping Model?
questions.option_a: A. Gather requirements
questions.explanation: Requirement gathering initiates the prototyping process to understand user expectations before building mock-ups.

questions.question: Which statement correctly describes the Incremental Model?
questions.option_a: A. The system is built in parts (increments)
questions.option_b: B. All features are released at once
questions.option_c: C. It focuses only on design
questions.explanation: The Incremental Model divides the system into smaller builds, delivering working parts incrementally.

questions.question: Which is an advantage of the Incremental Model?
questions.option_a: A. Early delivery of working software
questions.option_c: C. Risk concentration in one phase
questions.explanation: The model allows early releases that users can test and provide feedback on, accelerating value delivery.

questions.question: Which project best fits the Spiral Model?
questions.option_a: A. High-risk, complex aerospace system
questions.explanation: The Spiral Model is suitable for large, high-risk, and evolving projects that need continuous risk assessment.

questions.question: Which of the following is a phase in each loop of the Spiral Model?
questions.option_a: A. Planning
questions.explanation: Each spiral iteration includes planning, risk analysis, engineering, and evaluation stages.

questions.question: Which is a principle of the Agile Model?
questions.option_a: A. Customer collaboration
questions.explanation: Agile emphasizes close customer collaboration over strict adherence to documentation.

questions.question: Which of the following is a common Agile framework?
questions.option_a: A. Scrum
questions.explanation: Scrum is a widely used Agile framework based on iterative development and sprint planning.

questions.question: Which is a defining characteristic of Scrum?
questions.option_a: A. Sprint-based development cycles
questions.explanation: Scrum uses fixed-length sprints and defined roles such as Product Owner and Scrum Master.

questions.question: How do Scrum and Kanban differ?
questions.option_a: A. Scrum uses fixed-length sprints, Kanban uses continuous flow
questions.option_b: B. Kanban requires strict roles and meetings
questions.explanation: Scrum works in time-boxed sprints, while Kanban maintains a continuous, flow-based process.

questions.question: Which factor should be considered when choosing a software process model?
questions.option_a: A. Project size and complexity
questions.explanation: Project size and complexity significantly influence the suitability of a process model for a given project.
